title: Johnson & Johnson, Oklahoma Spar in Opioid Trial
summary: From 2007 to 2017, 4,653 Oklahomans died from unintentional prescription opioid overdoses, state's attorney general says in opening remarks. NORMAN, Okla.-Greed caused Oklahoma's devastating opioid epidemic, the state's attorney general told a packed courtroom.

title: America's Millennial Baby Bust
summary: Profound cultural shifts can't be overcome by pro-natalist subsidies.. Americans are having fewer children, and the latest news is that the U.S. birth rate has dipped to a 32-year low. A cross-party coalition in Washington thinks political intervention can mitigate the decline, but pump the brakes. Declining U.S. birth rates are the product of large cultural forces that the federal government can't buy off with subsidies or income transfers.

title: Supreme Court Rules in Favor of Police in Free-Speech Case
summary: Justices quash Alaska reveler's First Amendment lawsuit, dismiss claims of retaliatory arrest.. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court ruled Tuesday that police couldn't be sued for arresting a festivalgoer in Alaska who had contended officers targeted him for exercising his First Amendment rights.

title: Arms for the Saudis
summary: America's Middle East allies need weapons to defend against Iran.. President Trump is taking heat for bypassing Congress and selling billions of dollars in arms to Middle Eastern allies. title: Tennessee Voucher Victory
summary: The bill only applies to Memphis and Nashville, but it's a start.. Governor Bill Lee fulfilled a campaign promise on Friday when he signed a school voucher bill into law. title: A Court's Dangerous Antitrust Overreach
summary: Qualcomm licensed some of its chips 20 years ago. A judge says that obliges it to license all of them now.. Silicon Valley brought us a startling new creation last week. title: Who's Afraid of Robert Smith's Philanthropy?
summary: The billionaire promises to pay off a graduating class's student loans-and finds himself under attack.. Robert Smith was raised in a working-class Denver neighborhood in the 1970s. A high-school science class in his junior year sparked his interest in transistors, the building blocks of computers, cellphones and other electronic devices. Transistors were invented in the 1940s by AT&T 's Bell Labs, which had a facility not far from the teenager's home. He applied for a summer internship there but was told it was available only to juniors and seniors in college. Unbowed and impatient, he spent months pestering people in the human-resources department to give him a shot. Eventually, they did.

title: Get Serious About Burying Nuclear Waste
summary: Time for Congress to end the blockade against the Yucca Mountain project.. If the U.S. is serious about climate change, we must become serious about nuclear energy. Roughly 60% of America's carbon-free energy comes from nuclear power. That's more than three times the energy produced by wind and more than 18 times the amount from solar. Ninety-seven civilian nuclear plants generate roughly 20% of America's electricity.

title: 'Range' Review: Late Bloomers Bloom Best
summary: Late specialization demonstrably helped Roger Federer, Vincent van Gogh and Charles Darwin. It can serve the rest of us well, too.. Tiger Woods got an early start with golf: As we know, he was given a putter when he was seven months old and never let go. Less well-known is Roger Federer's path to the top. He dabbled before specializing and spent his boyhood engaged in a wide range of sports-including squash, wrestling and skateboarding-before gravitating, on his own, to tennis.

title: A Tariff Issue on Which Free and Fair Traders Can Agree
summary: Flawed WTO rules allow other countries to charge significantly higher duties than America does.. It is equally evident-with far more damage-in larger markets from China, the European Union and South Korea to India and Vietnam.

title: The Tension Between Marriage and Mission
summary: My wife knows what it is to have three homes in three different states in one year.. In a May 21 op-ed titled "Not Every Officer Wants to Be a General," Kate Bachelder Odell misses the point of the military reassignment process. In times of relative peace when the military is not fully mobilized for all-out war, the armed forces must ensure that there is a cadre of well-trained officers and noncommissioned officers who are ready to serve as commanders and in other essential positions in the case of mobilization, which includes both conscription and formation of new units. An excellent example is in World War II, when officers like Omar Bradley, George Patton, Dwight Eisenhower, Chester Nimitz, William Halsey and many others went from captain, major or commander to general or admiral almost overnight. My own father was promoted from captain to colonel in the space of a year and a half.

title: Lax Regulation on Airbnb Is Far From Consequence Free
summary: It has negatively affected many of the beautiful, quiet and family-oriented neighborhoods of my town.. I agree with your May 21 editorial "Making Room for Airbnb": The company is making the hotel market more competitive. However, the majority of Airbnbs are being opened in residential neighborhoods never zoned for commercial use. Properties in nice neighborhoods are snatched up by companies who operate Airbnb and vacation rentals and hire property managers. It has negatively affected many of the beautiful, quiet and family-oriented neighborhoods of my town and brings our property values down. Zoning boards see dollars coming into the city and only hear one side of the issue, but residents are left to deal with the disruption.

title: Immigrants Can Bolster the Population and Retirement
summary: 'Because immigrants into the U.S. are generally young, they increase the ratio of working-age population.'. While spotlighting the serious economic pressures on millennials, "Millennials Near Middle Age in Crisis" (page one, May 20) smuggles in fear-mongering about Social Security. Social Security's modest benefits are completely affordable. They would be even easier to afford, despite lower U.S. birthrates, if our nation rejects the xenophobia of Donald Trump and his compatriots, and instead welcomes immigrants. As Social Security's chief actuary has explained, "Because immigrants into the U.S. are generally young, they increase the ratio of working-age population to retirement-age population in much the same way as do births."

title: The Shockingly Large Business Behind the Iconic Smiley Face
summary: The trademarked smiley face symbol makes for a significant licensing business, one that is particularly successful as of late. EVERYONE KNOWS the ingredients of a smiley face: the egg-yolk circle, the black oblong eyes, the curved grin. It has pervaded pop culture since the 1960s, when hippies stickered it onto VW buses and screened it onto tie-dyed T-shirts. It guest-starred in the 1994 movie "Forrest Gump," when the titular character "invented" the sunny symbol. Generation-Xers will recall its ominpresence during the 1990s on everything from Joe Boxer underwear to raver backpacks; a dark version on Nirvana T-shirts replaced the eyes with Xs and added a subversive wobbliness to the grin.

title: Marco Bicego's Unico Necklaces

Jeweler Marco Bicego's collections are often paeans to landscapes around the world: His Siviglia pieces feature beads that mimic the cobblestone streets of Seville, Spain, while the Jaipur set borrows the Indian city's vibrant colors. For the two Unico necklaces featured here, hand-engraved in Bicego's headquarters in Trissino, Italy, he drew on travels through the Middle East and North Africa. The gold necklace at far left, set with rough-cut diamonds and pearls, was inspired by desert sands, while the piece at near left, strung with green tourmalines and diamonds, celebrates Africa's natural gemstones.

title: Do You Need a Champagne Decanter?
summary: You've heard the merits of decanting an old red. But what about bubbly? Enter Baccarat's fizz-friendly vessel (and our take on what to try with it). Let it breathe, says vintner Jean-Charles Boisset, whose Passion Collection Champagne Decanter, designed for Baccarat, dissipates the more vigorous bubbles and leaves what Boisset deems the most sophisticated ones. (Try it with the Charles Heidsieck Blanc des Millénaires Brut 1985, $590.) Thirty to 45 minutes of decanting, says Boisset, "gives another dimension to champagne." 800-221-6330 to preorder.

title: Wilco's Jeff Tweedy on Loving Problematic Art
summary: You sacrifice true awareness when you become an unquestioning fan, says the Wilco frontman and guitarist. Tweedy, writer Elaine Welteroth and others weigh in on this month's Columnists topic: sacrifice. "Sacrifice is being aware of an alternate path and continuing on the one that might be less comfortable, guided by some belief that the greater good is being served. I see true beauty in sacrifice. I see something essential and elemental. You need to be humbled; you need to be reminded of your role in the lives of others. I've loved art by a lot of people that have been empirically awful, and for a long time, I struggled with the dissonance between an artist's beautiful vision of the world and the selling of a horrible lifestyle as a justification for it. The problem is how often the artist gets emulated rather than the art. The lifestyle becomes a product. But what's being sacrificed is awareness, some kind of consciousness of one's own individuality. It wasn't the way I wanted to see myself, as this cliché. I needed help to come out on the other side."

title: A Day in the Life of Regina Hall
summary: The actress didn't commit to her craft until her 20s but has acted in 39 (and counting) productions. WSJ. tails her for the day. IF I HAD REALIZED how difficult it would be, I might not have done it," Regina Hall says of acting. Although Hall, 48, has worked consistently for more than two decades, it's her midcareer roles that have garnered her a new level of recognition. First came the surprise 2017 box office hit Girls Trip, co-starring Queen Latifah, Tiffany Haddish and Jada Pinkett Smith. Shortly after, Hall played the lead in the critically acclaimed independent film Support the Girls, a feel-good comedy about a compassionate bar manager. The one-two punch coincided with the mainstreaming of black Hollywood. For much of her career, Hall appeared in projects that proved popular (and profitable) with black audiences, including classics like Love & Basketball and The Best Man. But recently films with majority-African American casts, like Get Out and Black Panther, have been shattering box office records. As a result, the stars of such bold dramas and comedies are being tapped for even more big-budget studio projects. This month, for instance, Hall plays alongside Samuel L. Jackson in Shaft, director Tim Story's sequel to the 1971 hit blaxploitation film by the same name. (Hall had previously appeared in Story's 2012 Think Like a Man.) "It's wonderful to see people [you've worked with] get different opportunities," Hall says. "Box office really dictates what you're able to do next."

title: As Fiat Chrysler Pursues Renault Tie-Up, Nissan Weighs Stakes
summary: Proposed deal carries risks-and potential benefits-for Renault partner Nissan. A proposed merger between Renault SA and Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV poses risks for Nissan Motor Co. : The Japanese auto maker could lose influence in its two-decade alliance with Renault or get dropped altogether.

title: U.S.-China Trade Dispute Likely to Keep Bank of Canada On Hold
summary: While the Canadian economy is beginning to show some signs of spark after a slowdown that began in late 2018, the central bank might express more concern about global growth. The Bank of Canada is widely expected to leave its key interest rate on hold at an announcement this week as escalating U.S.-China trade tensions weigh on the economic outlook.

title: How Kids' Allowance Works in the Smartphone Age
summary: When it comes to teaching children about money, chore charts are out, electronic accounts are in. Allowances are a constant. No matter how much technology interferes with the parent-child relationship, kids still want money and parents still want to impart a basic work ethic. But putting stickers on chore charts and dropping coins in piggy banks don't cut it with the smartphone generation.

title: Fireworks for Retail Stocks Are a Dose of Reality
summary: The gap between winners and losers in retail is becoming clearer, but some investors have been caught out making wrong-way bets this quarter, leading to massive volatility. It has been another volatile earnings season for retailers, with stocks making big after-hours moves following their reports.

title: Time to Take Money Out of Indian Stocks
summary: Modi mania has made the country's stock market one of the world's most expensive. Prime Minister Narendra Modi's resounding success in last week's Indian elections may make for a strong government, but a strong stock market won't necessarily follow.

title: Technology-Focused Pilot Growth Leans on AI to Source Deals
summary: The firm's NavPod artificial intelligence system has helped track down and initiate eight of its 10 deals. Private-equity firms often employ herds of junior employees to comb through and cold-call companies to source deals. But technology-focused Pilot Growth Equity Partners has found that a system using artificial intelligence can do the job just as well.

title: Rise of New Hotel Brands Irks Some Property Owners
summary: Big hotel operators add new brands at fast clip, but strategy risks creating tension with property owners. Major hotel companies are introducing new brands at a rapid pace, a strategy that can boost revenue but one that risks confusing guests and alienating hotel owners.

title: No-Deal Brexit Could Ruin Breakfast in Britain
summary: Tomatoes, often delivered to U.K. wholesalers on the day they are picked, could face delays under a no-deal Brexit. The threat of a no-deal Brexit is back on the agenda, threatening to upend the seamless trade between Britain and the rest of Europe that businesses have relied on for decades.

title: Stock Investors Sound Alarm About New York's Office Market
summary: There is a nagging discount between REIT prices and valuation of properties they own. Property investors around the globe have been bidding up the price of Manhattan office towers for years. Now, the stock market is signaling they have pushed up values too far.

title: Facebook Ditches Commissions, Not Dollars
summary: Move to cut commissions on political ads makes headlines, has little financial impact. Facebook is finally getting smart about public relations by making important-sounding changes to its business that do virtually nothing to affect its bottom line.

title: Low-Volatility and 'Buffer' ETFs Draw Billions Amid Jitters Over Market Swings
summary: Two popular tactics: Picking stocks with steady performance, and limiting losses using options. With every bout of stock-market volatility, nervous investors start snapping up products meant to protect them in a downturn.

title: Global Investors Flock to India's First REIT After Launch by Blackstone
summary: IPO success for office-park trust encourages hope of creating new real-estate market in nation. India's first real-estate investment trust is off to a fast start, fueling global investor optimism that a new market for public real-estate companies could emerge there.

title: Tokyo Hotel Set for Trump Bump From Presidential Stay
summary: The usual spot where American presidents stay was closed, so Trump tried out the Palace Hotel. TOKYO-As a former real-estate magnate, President Trump might appreciate one clear winner from his four-day trip in Japan: the hotel where he stayed.

title: Behind FCA-Renault Talks: The Diverging Fates of Three Car Guys
summary: Resume Subscription. A death in Zurich, an arrest in Tokyo and a young heir who has long wanted to ease his family's dependence on the car business are the powerful human factors helping propel a proposed merger that could shake up the global auto industry.

title: Companies That Crack the Code for Coders
summary: Demand for development tools is growing rapidly as more companies develop their own software. The need for efficient software development is no longer confined to tech companies. But it is a task much easier said than done.

title: Alibaba Considers Listing in Hong Kong
summary: Years after it chose New York for its IPO, the Chinese e-commerce giant is looking to list closer to home. Chinese e-commerce titan Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. is weighing a plan to list in Hong Kong, according to people familiar with the matter, a move that would create a round-the-clock market for its shares and bring in more investors from the region.

title: Uber Drivers Seek Extra Cash Working for House Flippers
summary: Real-estate firms recruit drivers to help them find derelict properties to buy and sell fast. Brandon Taylor delivers food for UberEats and Amazon, but he has recently taken on another job: scouting potential targets for a house flipper.

title: Data Challenges Are Halting AI Projects, IBM Executive Says
summary: The cost and hassle of collecting and preparing data comes as a shock for some companies, according to Arvind Krishna. International Business Machines Corp. executive Arvind Krishna said data-related challenges are a top reason IBM clients have halted or canceled artificial-intelligence projects.

title: Mass Stabbing of Schoolchildren in Japan Leaves Two Dead
summary: An 11-year-old girl and a 39-year-old man were killed in the attack; the assailant was also confirmed dead. KAWASAKI, Japan-A man wielding two kitchen knives charged into a group of elementary-school girls waiting for a school bus in a Tokyo suburb, killing two people and injuring 16 others, officials said.

title: Trump Rallies Troops as Japan Trip Wraps Up
summary: President calls for more military spending for guided-missile destroyers, fast attack submarines and joint strike jet fighters. YOKOSUKA, Japan-President Trump wrapped up his Japan trip with Memorial Day addresses to troops on U.S. and Japanese Navy ships at a base south of Tokyo.

title: 529 Day: What to Consider When Choosing Education-Saving Plans
summary: ​Investors forgoing a broker and buying directly from a state can save money but should consider fees and potential tax benefits. April 20 and May 4th have earned spots in the collective imagination due to marijuana and "Star Wars." State governments and some investment firms hope May 29 can, too.

title: The Interstate Is Crumbling. Try Fixing the Section Used by 200,000 Vehicles a Day.
summary: Resume Subscription. ORLANDO, Fla.-The state dubbed it the I-4 Ultimate for its grand scope. For some here, it's more like the ultimate headache.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Illinois Voters to Decide Fate of Flat-Rate Tax
summary: Gov. Pritzker proposes graduated tax on incomes higher than $250,000. SPRINGFIELD, Ill.-Voters will decide whether to change Illinois's income-tax structure after the House approved a constitutional amendment on Gov. J.B. Pritzker's graduated tax proposal.

title: Sports Illustrated Sold for $110 Million to Licensing Company Authentic Brands
summary: Meredith will keep publishing magazine, while Authentic Brands will look to parlay Sports Illustrated name into licensing empire. Meredith Corp. agreed to sell Sports Illustrated for $110 million, more than a year after putting it on the block, but that doesn't mean the fabled sports magazine is leaving the family.

title: Fiat Chrysler Unveils Renault Merger Proposal
summary: Plan would create car company with combined value of about $37 billion. Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV proposed a roughly $40 billion merger with French rival Renault SA, a deal that if completed would create the third-largest auto maker by production and scramble an industry that has been seeking scale to cope with fast-globalizing markets and rapidly changing technology.

title: European Elections Deepen Divisions in National Capitals
summary: Vote for European Parliament became a referendum on countries' leaders. The outcome of the weekend's European Union elections threatened a fresh stage of political instability in the bloc, with results in many countries signaling disillusion with the establishment and polarization among voters.
